thread.title: Clint Bowyer will drive for HScott Motorsports before replacing Tony Stewart
thread.title_full: Clint Bowyer will drive for HScott Motorsports before replacing Tony Stewart

title: Clint Bowyer will drive for HScott Motorsports before replacing Tony Stewart
text:
USA TODAY Sports' Brant James on what everybody is talking about, what to watch for, and who will win in the AAA 400 at Dover International Speedway. USA TODAY Sports
Clint Bowyer will retain sponsor 5-Hour Energy when he moves to HScott Motorsports next season. (Photo: Aaron Doster, USA TODAY Sports)
2 CONNECT 1 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE DOVER, Del. — Clint Bowyer is becoming an expert at press conferences.
In his second formal meeting with media members in three days, Bowyer confirmed Friday at Dover International Speedway that he will drive for HScott Motorsports in the Sprint Cup Series in 2016.
The deal with the team owned by businessman Harry Scott is a one-year agreement. Bowyer will move on to Stewart-Haas Racing in 2017 to replace team co-owner Tony Stewart in the SHR No. 14 Chevrolet. Next season is scheduled to be Stewart’s last in the series, and the team announced Wednesday that Bowyer will be Stewart’s replacement.
USA TODAY
Gluck: Tony Stewart retiring from Sprint Cup racing on his terms
Bowyer currently drives for Michael Waltrip Racing, but that team is folding up shop at the end of this season.
HScott Motorsports, based in Spartanburg, S.C., will have a technical alliance with SHR next season. Sponsor 5-Hour Energy will join Bowyer at HScott, but the company has not decided if it will follow him to SHR in 2017.
Justin Allgaier and Michael Annett currently drive in the Cup series for HScott. Their situations for next season have not been determined, according to Scott.
“We haven’t ruled out anything for 2016 or beyond,” he said. “We simply don’t know at this point.”
USA TODAY
After spectacular summer, Chase misfortune bites Kyle Busch again
Bowyer said 2016 won’t be a “waiting” year for him. He expects a strong performance at HScott.
“We’re going to build a great program,” he said. “When I leave there, I want to be able to leave him with a winning organization and an established team to where he can put the next driver in and go for broke.
“We have everything in place — Hendrick (Motorsports) engines and ties to Stewart-Haas. Those are the guys who are winning the races.”
Meanwhile, Bowyer faces a tall task this weekend. He’s last in Chase points entering Sunday’s AAA 400, and he needs a Dover win to move on to the second round.
USA TODAY
Dover: Most recent wins for legends; pressure cooker for Chase drivers
“We’ve got a lot on the table,” Bowyer said. “We’ve got to win. Believe it not, last year’s champion (Kevin Harvick) has to win, as well.
“A lot of guys have a lot to lose, but I love this place. Your workload is through the roof at this place. How we don’t wreck every other lap around this place is beyond me.”
Follow Hembree on Twitter @mikehembree

Clint Bowyer, born May 30, 1979 in Emporia, Kan., drives the No. 15 Toyota for Michael Waltrip Racing. Sam Sharpe, USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen Clint Bowyer celebrates after edging Richard Childress Racing teammate Kevin Harvick for the win at Talladega in October 2011. Cooper, USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen Clint Bowyer, right, drove for owner Richard Childress, left, in NASCAR's three top series from 2004 through 2011. Kevin C. Cox, Getty Images for NASCAR Fullscreen Clint Bowyer celebrates with a bottle of champagne and the championship trophy after winning the 2008 NASCAR Nationwide Series title. Rebilas, USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen Clint Bowyer does a burnout after scoring his first career NASCAR Cup win at the Sylvania 300 at New Hampshire Motor Speedway on Sept. 16, 2007. Al Bello, Getty Images Fullscreen Clint Bowyer won his first career NASCAR Cup pole at the Dodge Avenger 500 at Darlington Raceway on May 11, 2007. Willis Glassgow, AP Fullscreen Clint Bowyer drove a Chevrolet sponsored by HBO's hit series "The Sopranos" for the 2006 race at Las Vegas Motor Speedway. Bowyer, third from right, poses with cast members (from left to right) Frank Vincent, Joe Gannascoli, Vincent Curatola, Steve Schirripa, and John Ventimiglia.
